key_points: The U.S. Senate confirmed federal judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The vote was 53-44, with all opposition coming from Republicans and three Republicans voting with Democrats.
President Joe Biden nominated Jackson, seen as a potential Supreme Court nominee and a historic choice as the first Black woman.
Jackson replaces Attorney General Merrick Garland on the D.C. Circuit, a common precursor to Supreme Court appointment.
Jackson, aged 50, was previously appointed to her district court position by former President Barack Obama in 2013.
During her confirmation hearing, Jackson refuted the idea that race plays a role in her judicial decisions.
Democrats currently have control of the Senate, which is split 50-50, with Vice President Kamala Harris available for tie-breaking votes.
Liberal activists have urged Stephen Breyer, the Supreme Court's oldest liberal justice, to retire while Democrats hold the Senate.
Jackson, a Harvard Law School graduate, once clerked for Justice Stephen Breyer.
Jackson and California Supreme Court Justice Leondra Kruger are viewed as front-runners for a Supreme Court nomination if Breyer retires.
